title: How to Use Anki: A Beginner Tutorial
note: Practical guide to getting started with Anki for any subject.
author: Lean Anki

title: Create Your First Anki Deck
note: Download Anki and create a deck of 20 cards on a topic you want to learn. Use it daily for one week.

title: The Feynman Technique
note: Farnam Street's comprehensive guide to Richard Feynman's four-step learning method.
author: Farnam Street

title: The Feynman Learning Technique
note: Deep dive into teaching as learning and the rubber duck debugging method.
author: Farnam Street

title: Metacognitive Study Strategies
note: UNC Learning Center guide to thinking about your thinking while learning.
author: UNC Learning Center

title: Metacognition - MIT Teaching Lab
note: MIT's guide to planning, monitoring, and evaluating your own learning process.
author: MIT Teaching + Learning Lab

title: Metacognitive Strategies - Cornell
note: Practical exercises for developing metacognitive awareness in any subject.
author: Cornell Center for Teaching Innovation

title: Fostering Metacognition to Support Student Learning
note: Research-backed guide highlighting self-testing, spacing, and interleaving as key strategies.
author: CBE Life Sciences Education

title: Feynman Technique Practice
note: Pick a concept you recently learned. Explain it in writing as if teaching a 12-year-old. Identify gaps and iterate.

title: What's Worth Measuring? Assessment in the AI Age
note: UNESCO on shifting from rote knowledge to higher-order thinking and ethical reasoning.
author: UNESCO

title: Thinking About Assessment with Generative AI
note: Columbia Teachers College on designing assessments that evaluate authentic learning.
author: Columbia Digital Futures Institute

title: AI Teaching Strategies - Stanford
note: Stanford's practical guide for educators on incorporating AI thoughtfully.
author: Stanford Center for Teaching and Learning

title: Strategies for Personalized Learning in AI Age
note: Pedagogical methods that work regardless of new technologyâ€”generative learning and flipped classrooms.
author: Inside Higher Ed

title: AI Can Deliver Personalized Learning at Scale
note: Dartmouth research on AI tutors using Socratic questioning and spaced retrieval practice.
author: Dartmouth News

title: The Science of Learning - Barbara Oakley at Coursera
note: Interview with Barbara Oakley on applying neuroscience insights to become a better learner.
author: Coursera Blog

title: Design Your Learning System
note: Create a personal learning protocol combining techniques from this syllabus. Include daily, weekly, and monthly habits.

title: Philosophy of Education - Stanford Encyclopedia
note: Comprehensive overview of educational philosophy from ancient Greece to contemporary debates. Essential foundation for the syllabus.
author: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy

title: The Philosopher King: Education in Plato's Republic
note: How Plato designed a 35-year education for guardians culminating in knowledge of the Form of the Good.
author: Medium

title: Education in Plato's Republic - Santa Clara University
note: The Allegory of the Cave as a model for education - liberation from ignorance toward understanding of reality.
author: Santa Clara University

title: Aristotle on Education - Britannica
note: Aristotle's emphasis on virtue development through community-guided practice and moral character formation.
author: Britannica

title: Rousseau's Emile - Representing Childhood
note: Rousseau's revolutionary child-centered approach: 'Everything is good as it leaves the hands of the Author of things.'
author: University of Pittsburgh

title: Rousseau's Errors in Educational Theory
note: Critical analysis: the vulnerable-child fallacy and controllability fallacy in Rousseau's thinking.
author: Psychology Today

title: Classical Philosophy Comparison
note: Write a 500-word essay comparing Plato, Aristotle, and Rousseau on the fundamental purpose of education. Which philosopher's vision most resonates with your own experience?

title: Dewey's Educational Philosophy - The Education Hub
note: Dewey's pragmatism: cultivating thoughtful, critically reflective individuals through experience rather than rote learning.
author: The Education Hub

title: John Dewey - Stanford Encyclopedia
note: Comprehensive overview of Dewey's philosophy including his landmark 'Democracy and Education' (1916).
author: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy

title: Dewey and Citizenship Education
note: How education and democracy are organically connected - each serving as a condition for the other.
author: ResearchGate

title: Newman on Education - Cardinal Newman Society
note: Newman's vision: liberal education as 'real cultivation of mind' - a connected view and grasp of things.
author: Cardinal Newman Society

title: The Idea of a University - Newman Reader
note: Newman's Discourse VII: Knowledge as its own end - the intellect disciplined for its own sake, not for specific trades.
author: Newman Reader

title: A Remedy to Misconceptions: Newman's Idea of a University
note: The university's purpose is to train minds to comprehend truth - it makes thinkers, not saints.
author: Word on Fire

title: Analyze Your Educational Experience
note: Reflect on your own education through Dewey's and Newman's lenses. Did it prepare you for democratic citizenship? Did it cultivate your mind for its own sake? Write a personal analysis (600 words).

title: Education in Ancient Greece - Wikipedia
note: From elementary grammatistes to Plato's Academy - how the Greeks invented formal education.
author: Wikipedia

title: Ancient Higher Education - Philosophy of Education
note: Plato's Academy (387 BCE), Aristotle's Lyceum (335 BCE), and the Imperial University of Constantinople (425 CE).
author: Taylor & Francis

title: Athens: Elementary and Higher Education - Britannica
note: The three masters of Greek elementary education and how the Sophists revolutionized higher learning.
author: Britannica

title: Medieval Universities - Vaia
note: The seven liberal arts: trivium (grammar, rhetoric, logic) and quadrivium (arithmetic, astronomy, geometry, music).
author: Vaia

title: What Did Medieval Universities Teach?
note: 8-9 years for liberal arts, then theology, medicine, or law. How Aristotle became central to Scholasticism.
author: History Hit

title: History of College - From Bologna to Today
note: Bologna (1088), Paris (1150), Oxford (1167) - how medieval institutions shaped modern universities.
author: My Front Page Story

title: Curriculum Evolution Map
note: Create a visual timeline showing how educational curriculum evolved from the trivium/quadrivium to modern disciplines. Identify which classical subjects survive and which disappeared.

title: MOOCs Didn't Achieve Their Goals - Inside Higher Ed
note: MIT/Harvard study: completion rates barely budged, 68.7% of students from developed countries. The democratization promise unfulfilled.
author: Inside Higher Ed

title: The MOOC Problem - Hybrid Pedagogy
note: Critical analysis: MOOCs underperformed traditional models with no large-scale cost benefit despite the hype.
author: Hybrid Pedagogy

title: MOOCs and Technology Access Barriers
note: How technology access limits MOOCs' democratizing potential - governmental action needed for equity.
author: ResearchGate

title: Contextualizing Khan Academy - World Bank
note: The Matthew Effect in edtech: the best teachers get the greatest impact, flexibility can harm low-capacity systems.
author: World Bank Blogs

title: Con Academy - Hedgehog Review
note: Critical examination of Khan Academy's AI hype and the 'technology is not good or bad' clichÃ©.
author: Hedgehog Review

title: Epistemology and Education
note: How theories of knowledge shape educational practice - from justified true belief to constructivism.
author: Encyclopedia.com

title: EdTech Democratization Audit
note: Choose an educational platform (Coursera, Khan Academy, Duolingo, etc.) and evaluate its democratization claims. Who actually benefits? What barriers remain? Present your findings in a 2-page analysis.
